Award.AwardTitle: Micro-Submersible Lake Exploration Device (MSLED) - Development of first-generation propelled slim-hole device for subglacial lake (& aquatic environments) exploration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for "Micro-Submersible Lake Exploration Device (MSLED)- Development of first-generation propelled slim-hole device for subglacial lake (& aquatic environments) exploration" from the Antarctic Integrated System Science within the Office of Polar Programs. Subglacial environments represent one of the last unexplored habitats on Earth. To get to subglacial environments one must first drill through the ice. Drill holes are typically limited in diameter to approximately 30 cm (~ten inches), and all subglacial explorations are currently limited to slim equipment that will remain directly beneath the drill hole. The proposed MSLED will be the only piece of equipment to "swim" away from the hole in a subglacial environment, thus greatly increasing the range of exploration.

Intellectual Merit: The award provides funding for development of a swimming camera and sensor platform that is small enough to be deployed down a slim borehole. The MSLED will have a camera, and also be equipped with a limited suite of chemical sensors to include temperature, salinity, pH, and pressure. While the current award is only for development and initial field testing of the MSLED through the sea ice, it is envisioned that the MSLED will be very useful for recent projects that NSF has funded within the Pine Island Glacier and Whillans Ice Stream areas. Understanding subglacial dynamics in the Antarctic is critical for improving predictive models of land-ice loss that in turn is critical for understanding how fast sea level may rise in the next century.

Broader Impact: Exploring new environments has great inherent interest. Cameras are a great tool to provide a quick look at totally unexplored locations, and imagery from such explorations is a great way to engage the public. The development of the MSLED draws heavily on design contributions from students (both graduate and undergraduate), and will bring a student to Antarctica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Micro Sub-glacial Lake Exploration Device (MSLED) project focuses on the exploration of sub-glacial lakes with the WISSARD project in Antarctica and student opportunity. MSLED creates a platform for the smallest high depth robotic diver in the world and with its skinny body it is meant to be deployed down boreholes through the ice to explore hidden bodies of water below. In 2011 MSLED was deployed and tested in Antarctica exploring the Ross Sea and testing the deployment and maneuverability of the vehicle. In 2012-2013 MSLED accompanied the team of WISSARDs to explore the sub-glacial Lake Whillans. MSLED has spent the first part of this mission exploring the Ross Sea underneath the Ross Ice Shelf. After a 14 day traverse across Antarctica from the America base McMurdo to the Whillans ice stream, MSLED will enter the isolated lake and explore a world that has never seen the light of day. With MSLED’s high definition camera, sensors, and lights, it will study the lake bed and the water to ice interface. This mission is to take place January 2013 with Alberto Behar and student.

MSLED has successfully delivered sensor data live back to the surface for immediate evaluation of the underwater environment as well as live streaming video of the descent down an ice borehole and the sea bed. One of the benefits of MSLED from other scientific devices is its adaptability to study an environment. It can experience a sudden change in the environment and be piloted to further observe the situation. It has a powerful thruster and fins to help maneuver it away from the borehole and can explore as far as a kilometer under the ice!  

MSLED has been deployed not only in Antarctica but also lakes across the southwest of the United States. From Lake Tahoe to Lake Bartlett in Arizona, MLSED has been exploring and testing its limits with its team of largely undergraduate students. Under the advice of Dr. Behar, the students work on designing MSLED to be more robust, efficient, and elegant. This project has provided educational opportunities to over 20 undergraduate students allowing them to get real hands on experience and design and build an underwater vehicle capable of diving down 1.2 kilometers! Most student projects have trouble leaving the classroom but for those working on MSLED, they see applications for all over the world. Many of the students have continued to other opportunities including Boeing, NASA, and research at the National Laboratories.
